Legal Studies 206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students engage in a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. Through these exercises and associated readings, students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills.  This course is cross-listed as MGMT 291, OPIM 291, and LGST 206.

All the students who wrote reviews loved this course.  “Best course,” “my favorite class at Penn,” and the “most interesting and practical class I have taken at Penn” were among the comments reiterated across the reviews.  Students “learned a lot” and emphasized the practical implications of the knowledge they gained, saying that they would use what they “learned in this course on a regular basis for the rest of their lives.”  Several also noted that they “learned more about others – and themselves– than they ever expected.” 

Students also universally praised Professor Shell.  They described him as “amazing,” “engaging,” and “the best professor at Penn.”  Several students praised Professor Shell’s knowledge, noting that he is “clearly at the top of his field.” Others wrote that he was “unbelievably good at stimulating interest.” 

Students emphasized that “everyone at Penn can benefit from this course.”  A few students had complaints about graded negotiations and alluded to “competitive” grading, but students’ appreciation of the course as a whole overshadowed these comments.  There are no prerequisites.

Legal Studies 206 examines the art and science of negotiation, with additional emphasis on conflict resolution. Students explore the basic theoretical models of bargaining and have an opportunity to test and improve their negotiation skills through a number of simulated negotiations ranging from simple one-issue transactions to multi-party joint ventures. 

Students found this course to be both informative and enjoyable. They found the information taught in the course to be useful and relevant. However, some students described the amount of reading assigned as “unreasonable” and “extremely repetitive.”

Students raved about Professor Bergman, finding him to be extremely knowledgeable in his field and passionate about teaching. Their reviews described Professor Bergman using words such as “wonderful,” “awesome” and “a nice person.” One student reported Professor Bergman as “one of their favorite teachers.” Professor Bergman’s personality created a comfortable classroom atmosphere, which his students enjoyed.

The grades in this class were not based on the results of the negotiations, which gave students “more leeway to try out different strategies” and made the course “less competitive and stressful.” However, students had difficulty managing the prolific amount of reading that was assigned, finding it quite onerous. Students recommended this class for every student, claiming the information would be useful for anyone.
